questions.text: Which of the following is the correct definition of shock?

choices.text: A state of low tissue perfusion inadequate for normal cellular respiration.
A state of high tissue perfusion inadequate for normal cellular respiration.
A state of low tissue perfusion adequate for normal cellular respiration.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) A state of low tissue perfusion inadequate for normal cellular respiration.

Explanation:

 

Shock is defined as a systemic state of low tissue perfusion which is inadequate for normal cellular respiration.

Classification of shock in table format:

Type of Shock

Mechanism

Examples

Hypovolemic Shock

Reduced circulating blood volume

Hemorrhage, Dehydration

Cardiogenic Shock

Failure of the cardiac pump

Myocardial Infarction, Cardiac Dysrhythmias

Obstructive Shock

Mechanical obstruction of cardiac filling

Cardiac Tamponade, Tension Pneumothorax

Distributive Shock

Systemic vasodilation leading to organ hypoperfusion

Septic Shock, Anaphylactic Shock

Endocrine Shock

Combination of hypovolemic, cardiogenic, or distributive shock mechanisms

Addisonian Crisis, Myxedema Coma

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient was brought with multiple injuries on his body following a road traffic accident. O/E patient was drowsy and confused, extremities were cold and clammy, weak thready pulse noted. On auscultation, tachypnoea and tachycardia observed. Identify the type of shock seen in this patient.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Hypovolemic shock

 

Explanation:

Hypovolemic shock is likely to be seen in this patient due to hemorrhage (Option A)

 

Pathophysiology:

 

Clinical features of hypovolemic shock:

  • Cold and clammy skin - due to inadequate tissue perfusion.
  • Reduced renal blood flow and GFR lead to oliguria which may lead to anuria.
  • Cerebral blood flow is reduced leading to drowsiness and confusion.
  • Tachypnoea - due to lactic acidosis
  • Tachycardia
  • Weak thready pulse
  • Sweating

 

Option B: In Distributive shock, there will be systemic vasodilation leading to organ hypoperfusion as seen mainly in anaphylaxis due to histamine release, sepsis due to the release of bacterial products

 

Option C: Neurogenic shock refers to reduced tissue perfusion due to loss of vasomotor tone to peripheral arterial beds. It usually occurs secondary to spinal cord injury

 

Option D: Cardiogenic shock is due to the primary failure of the heart to pump blood. It may be due to myocardial infarction, cardiomyopathy, or blunt myocardial injury

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient was brought to the emergency department following a road traffic accident.O/E, he had multiple injuries all over his body and was found to be in class III hemorrhagic shock. The percentage of blood loss would be between:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 30-40%

 

Explanation:

The percentage of blood loss in class III hemorrhagic shock is 30-40%.



 

Parameter

Class I (Compensated Shock)

Class II (Hypoxemia)

Class III

Class IV (Refractory Shock)

Blood Loss

Up to 15% (Option A)

15-30% (Option D)

30-40% (Option B)

More than 40% (Option C)

Mechanism

Compensatory mechanisms maintain cardiac output.

Generalized vasoconstriction.

Decompensated shock.

Refractory shock.

Heart Rate

<100/min

100-120/min

120-140/min

>140/min

Blood Pressure

Normal

Hypotension

Marked hypotension

Profound hypotension

Respiratory Rate

Normal

Tachypnea

Tachypnea

Tachypnea

Urine Output

>30 ml/hour

20-30 ml/hour

5-15 ml/hour

No urine output

Mental Status

Alert, normal

Anxious, mildly agitated

Confused, altered mental status

Comatose, lethargic

questions.text: Following a road traffic accident, a 23-year-old man presents with multiple injuries on his body and the percentage of blood loss is <15%. Identify which class of ATLS classification it belongs to.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: (A) Class1

 

Explanation:

 

In ATLS Class 1, the percentage of blood loss is less than 15%. In this stage, the patient's BP will be normal, urine output >30 mL/hr, and the patient will be in a slightly anxious state.

 

Advanced Trauma Life Support (ATLS) Classes of Hypovolemic Shock

 

Parameter

Class I

Class II

Class III

Class IV

Blood loss (%)

0-15%

15-30%

30-40%

> 40%

Central Nervous System (CNS)

Slightly anxious

Mildly anxious

Anxious or confused

Confused or lethargic

Pulse (beats/min)

< 100

> 100

> 120

> 140

Blood pressure

Normal

Normal

Decreased

Decreased

Pulse pressure

Normal

Decreased

Decreased

Decreased

Respiratory rate (breaths/min)

14-20

20-30

30-40

> 35

Urine output (mL/hr)

> 30

20-30

5-15

Negligible/Nil

Fluid requirement

Crystalloid

Crystalloid

Crystalloid + Blood

Crystalloid + Blood

Base deficit (mEq/L)

0 to -2

-2 to -6

-6 to -10

-10 or less

questions.text: A 62-year-old male with a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes presents with chest pain. His ECG shows ST-segment elevation in the anterior leads. Despite initial treatment, his condition deteriorates with low blood pressure, rapid heart rate, and difficulty breathing. Examination reveals elevated jugular venous pressure (JVP) and crackles on lung auscultation. What type of shock is this patient most likely experiencing?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: (A) Cardiogenic shock

 

Explanation:

Cardiogenic shock is seen in myocardial depression as a result of infarction.

Category

Cause

Systolic Dysfunction
  • Myocardial Infarction (MI)
  • Myocardial Depressants:
  1. Calcium Channel Blockers (CCBs)
  2. Beta Blockers
  3. Anti-arrhythmic drugs

Diastolic Dysfunction
  • Ventricular Hypertrophy
  • Restrictive Cardiomyopathy
  • Cardiac Tamponade

Valvular Structural Abnormalities
  • Papillary Muscle Rupture
  • Aortic Regurgitation (AR)
  • Mitral Regurgitation (MR)

Arrhythmias
  • Ventricular Tachyarrhythmia
     

 

Obstructive shock (Option B) is characterized by a reduction in preload due to mechanical obstruction of the cardiac filling of the left and/or right side of the heart, which in turn leads to a fall in cardiac output.

 

Hypovolemic shock (Option C) is likely to be seen in this patient due to hemorrhage.

 

Septic shock (Option D) is the release of bacterial products (endotoxin) and the activation of cellular and humoral components of the immune system.

questions.text: A patient admitted to the hospital with a urinary tract infection develops oliguria and lightheadedness on the third day of admission. His peripheries are warm, capillary refill is brisk, and his blood pressure is noted to be 86/56 mmHg despite fluid resuscitation. What type of shock is this patient likely experiencing?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Septic shock

 

Explanation: The given presentation is seen in septic shock.

Sepsis+hypotension for at least 1 hour, despite adequate fluid resuscitation (SBP<90 mmHg/40mmhg less than normal BP)

  • In septic shock, the extremities are warm, and capillary refill will be brisk.
  • Septic shock is initiated by -bacteria, fungi, and viruses (Option B)

Pathophysiology of Septic Shock

Infection (insult/injury)

↓

Release of inflammatory mediators

↓

Systemic inflammatory response

↓

Diffuse endothelial injury, vasodilation, and increased capillary permeability

↓

Progressive vasodilation and maldistribution of blood flow

↓

Organ hypoperfusion

↓

Multiple organ dysfunction syndrome (MODS)

 

Clinical Features:

  • Fever.
  • Chills and rigor.
  • Evidence of local infection at the site.
  • Hypotension.
  • Rapid capillary filling.
  • Bounding pulse.
  • Vasodilation - leads to warm peripheries.



 

Option A: Reduced circulating blood volume leads to hypovolemic shock, likely to be seen in a patient due to hemorrhage.

 

Option C: Obstructive shock is characterized by a reduction in preload due to mechanical obstruction of the cardiac filling of the left and/or right side of the heart, which in turn leads to fall in cardiac output

 

Option D: Cardiogenic shock is due to the primary failure of the heart to pump blood. It may be due to myocardial depression as a result of infarction, cardiomyopathy, or blunt myocardial injury

questions.text: A 42-year-old man is brought after a high-impact motor vehicle accident. On examination, he has a spinal cord injury at the level of T6 with flaccid paralysis of the lower extremities. His vital signs show hypotension, bradycardia, and warm, flushed skin. Which of the following is the most likely underlying pathophysiologic mechanism for his shock state?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: (D) Decreased peripheral vascular resistance

 

Explanation:

Neurogenic shock

 

In neurogenic shock, there is a loss of sympathetic tone leading to vasodilation of the peripheral vasculature, resulting in decreased peripheral vascular resistance and hypotension. This is the primary mechanism underlying neurogenic shock.

 

Causes:

  • Neurogenic shock is a critical condition that results from the dysregulation of the autonomic nervous system following spinal cord injury, especially in the cervical and upper thoracic vertebrae above the T6 level, as a result of traumatic events. The dysregulation arises due to the lack of sympathetic tone and decreased peripheral vascular resistance (Option D)
  • The decline in sympathetic tone prompts the dilation of capacitance blood vessels in the lower extremities. This, in turn, results in decreased cardiac filling, leading to hypotension and shock.
  • Reduced sympathetic control over the heart leads to a situation where unopposed vagal cardiac influence causes bradycardia.
  • Patients with neurogenic shock may also exhibit pink and warm skin due to the dilation of subcutaneous blood vessels.
  • Severe brain injury
  • Certain anesthetics

 

Pathophysiology

 

Clinical Manifestations:

  • Hypotension
  • Bradycardia (unlike other forms of shock)
  • Warm, dry skin below injury level
  • Priapism in males
  • Respiratory compromise (if high cervical injury)
  • Poikilothermia (inability to regulate body temperature)

 

Decreased cardiac output (Option A): In neurogenic shock, the cardiac output is usually maintained or increased due to the loss of sympathetic vasoconstrictor tone.

 

Decreased blood volume (Option B): Neurogenic shock is not associated with decreased blood volume, unlike hypovolemic shock.

 

Increased vascular permeability (Option C): is more characteristic of distributive shock like septic shock, not neurogenic shock.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old male presents with a sudden onset of severe fatigue, weakness, nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain. On examination, he is hypotensive (BP 75/45 mmHg), tachycardic (HR 115 bpm), and has noticeable diffuse skin hyperpigmentation, especially in sun-exposed areas and palmar creases. Laboratory results reveal:


	Sodium: 128 mEq/L
	Potassium: 5.8 mEq/L
	Glucose: 58 mg/dL


What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: (C) Addison's disease

 

Explanation:

 

Addison's disease, or primary adrenal insufficiency, is characterized by the destruction of the adrenal cortex, leading to deficient production of cortisol and aldosterone.

 

In an acute crisis, patients present with severe hypotension, electrolyte imbalances (low sodium, high potassium), hypoglycemia, and dehydration, which are all seen in this patient.

 

Diffuse skin hyperpigmentation occurs due to increased ACTH levels stimulating melanocytes, which is a hallmark of Addison's disease.

 

Clinical features:

  • Hypotension, shock resistant to fluid resuscitation
  • Nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain
  • Weakness, fatigue
  • Confusion, delirium
  • Fever (may be absent in the elderly)

Laboratory findings:

  • Hyponatremia, hyperkalemia
  • Hypoglycemia
  • Metabolic acidosis
  • Low serum cortisol (< 18 μg/dL is suggestive, < 3 μg/dL is diagnostic in stressed patients)

Management:

  • Immediate hydrocortisone: 100 mg IV bolus, followed by 50-100 mg every 6-8 hours
  • Fluid resuscitation: Normal saline 1-2 L in first hour, then as needed
  • Glucose administration if hypoglycemic
  • Treat precipitating factors (e.g., infection)

Subsequent evaluation:

  • Once stabilized, perform ACTH stimulation test to confirm diagnosis
  • Measure plasma ACTH to differentiate primary from secondary adrenal insufficiency
  • Investigate underlying cause (e.g., autoimmune, infectious, malignant)

Long-term management:

  • Daily glucocorticoid and mineralocorticoid replacement
  • Patient education on stress dosing and emergency management

 

Diabetic ketoacidosis (Option A) typically presents with hyperglycemia, not hypoglycemia. The electrolyte pattern and skin hyperpigmentation are not consistent with DKA.

 

Septic shock (Option B) can cause hypotension and tachycardia, but doesn't explain electrolyte abnormalities, or skin hyperpigmentation. Septic shock typically causes hyperglycemia, not hypoglycemia.

 

Panhypopituitarism (Option D) can cause secondary adrenal insufficiency, but it wouldn't result in skin hyperpigmentation (due to low ACTH levels). Also, the electrolyte abnormalities are typically less severe in secondary adrenal insufficiency because aldosterone production is usually preserved.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient is brought to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain, tachycardia, and hypotension. Examination reveals pale, cool, and clammy skin with delayed capillary refill. The patient has oliguria. Which of the following hemodynamic profiles is most characteristic of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) SVR - ↑ ; CO - ↓ ; CVP - ↓

 

Explanation:

The clinical presentation of tachycardia, hypotension, pale and cool skin, and oliguria is characteristic of hypovolemic shock. In this condition, there is an increase in systemic vascular resistance as a compensatory mechanism to maintain blood pressure, but a decreased cardiac output due to the reduced intravascular volume. The central venous pressure is typically decreased due to the hypovolemic state.

 

Options A, C, and D are incorrect

 

Physiological Hemodynamic Characteristics of Shock

 

Type of Shock

Cardiac Output

Systemic Vascular Resistance

Central Venous Pressure

Mean Arterial Pressure

Hypovolemic

↓

↑

↓

↓

Cardiogenic

↓

↑

↑

↓

Distributive(Septic, anaphylactic, neurogenic)

↑ or ↓

↓

↓ or N

↓

Obstructive (pulmonary embolism, cardiac tamponade, tension pneumothorax)

↓

↑

↑

↓

questions.text:
A 65-year-old patient presents with sudden onset of shortness of breath, tachycardia, and hypotension. Examination reveals cool, clammy skin, and delayed capillary refill. The most appropriate initial management strategy for this patient's condition would be

:

choices.text: Fluid resuscitation with normal saline and initiation of norepinephrine
Fluid resuscitation with Ringer's lactate and initiation of dobutamine
Fluid resuscitation with normal saline and initiation of dopamine
Fluid resuscitation with Ringer's lactate and initiation of epinephrine

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: (A) Fluid resuscitation with normal saline and initiation of norepinephrine

 

Explanation:

Based on the clinical presentation of tachycardia, hypotension, and poor peripheral perfusion, this patient is likely in hypovolemic or distributive shock.

  • The initial management should focus on fluid resuscitation with normal saline, as it is the preferred crystalloid for volume replacement in shock.
  • Crystalloids and Norepinephrine are the drug of choice for distributive and hypovolemic shock, as it helps to restore vascular tone and maintain blood pressure.

Parameters used to assess shock

Parameter

Normal/Target Value

Shock Indicator

Clinical Significance

Blood Pressure (Systolic BP)

≥ 90 mmHg

< 90 mmHg or a drop > 40 mmHg from baseline

Indicates hypotension and decreased perfusion to vital organs.

Mean Arterial Pressure (MAP)

> 65 mmHg

< 65 mmHg

MAP below 65 mmHg may result in inadequate organ perfusion.

Heart Rate (HR)

60-100 bpm

> 100 bpm

Tachycardia is a compensatory response to maintain perfusion.

Urine Output

≥ 0.5 mL/kg/hour

< 0.5 mL/kg/hour

Low urine output indicates renal hypoperfusion.

Lactate Levels

0.5-1 mmol/L

> 2 mmol/L

Elevated lactate suggests anaerobic metabolism and hypoxia.

Central Venous Oxygen Saturation (ScvO2)

70-75%

< 70%

Indicates imbalance between oxygen delivery and consumption.

Skin Temperature & Capillary Refill

Warm, capillary refill < 2 seconds

Cold, clammy skin, capillary refill > 2 seconds

Suggests poor peripheral perfusion and possible shock.





 

Type of Shock

Drug of Choice (DOC)

Rationale

Secondary Options

Hypovolemic Shock

Intravenous fluids (crystalloids or colloids)

Restore intravascular volume

Blood products if hemorrhagic shock

Cardiogenic Shock

Inotropes (e.g., Dobutamine)

Improve cardiac contractility

Vasopressors (e.g., Norepinephrine) if hypotension persists

Distributive Shock

Vasopressors (e.g., Norepinephrine)

Counteract vasodilation and increase systemic vascular resistance

Vasopressin as a second-line agent

Obstructive Shock

Treat underlying cause (e.g., thrombolysis for pulmonary embolism, pericardiocentesis for cardiac tamponade)

Address the cause of obstruction

Intravenous fluids and vasopressors as needed

Anaphylactic Shock

Epinephrine

Potent vasoconstrictor and bronchodilator

Antihistamines, corticosteroids
